\text{Using trignometric identity,}\\
\begin{align}
\sin 3 x &= 3 \sin x - 4 \sin^3 x \\
\implies \sin^3 (2x+1) &= \dfrac{3 \sin (2 x+1) - \sin 3 (2x +1)}{4} \end{align}\\
\therefore \int \sin^3 (2x+1) dx \\ \quad \qquad \qquad = \int \dfrac{3 \sin (2 x+1) - \sin (6x +3)}{4} dx
